abstract.p: Frances R Curcio letter on urgency of improving the teaching of mathematics in New York City public schools (Oct 13 article)

block.p: As a member of former Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez's working group that released a report on the state of mathematics education in New York City public schools in June 1990, I am deeply saddened and troubled by the results of the New York State eighth-grade mathematics test (news article, Oct. 13).

As a member of former Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez's working group that released a report on the state of mathematics education in New York City public schools in June 1990, I am deeply saddened and troubled by the results of the New York State eighth-grade mathematics test (news article, Oct. 13).

After 10 years and several chancellors, middle-school children in our poorest communities continue to be the victims of inadequate instruction, deficient curriculums and lack of resources, impeding their opportunity to learn and to meet the standards. I eagerly look forward to the results of Chancellor Harold O. Levy's panel to see how we can improve the conditions of teaching and learning mathematics in our city schools. Our children's and our city's future depend on it.
FRANCES R. CURCIO Flushing, Queens, Oct. 13, 2000
The writer is a professor of mathematics education at Queens College.
